name: Murabaha: Asset Ownership Before Sale (Hard Gate)
description: HARD GATE: Institution must own asset/commodity in its inventory before selling to customer. Selling what you don't own is prohibited (bay' al-ma'dum)

steps.title: Purchase Asset from Supplier
steps.description: Institution purchases asset/commodity from supplier using its own funds

requiredEvidence.description: Supplier's invoice showing institution as buyer
Proof of payment to supplier (bank transfer, check)

policyConstraints.constraint: Institution must purchase asset before selling to customer - cannot sell what it doesn't own

steps.title: Asset Entry into Inventory
steps.description: Record asset in institution's inventory system with valuation at cost

requiredEvidence.description: Accounting entry recording asset in institution's inventory
Valuation at cost (acquisition price + incidental costs)
Physical evidence of asset in institution's possession (if applicable)
Evidence showing asset was owned for constructive possession period

policyConstraints.constraint: Asset must be in institution's inventory before Murabaha sale to customer
Institution must bear ownership risk (even briefly) - cannot pass directly from supplier to customer

steps.title: SCO Ownership Verification Before Sale
steps.description: SCO verifies that institution owned asset before executing Murabaha sale contract with customer

requiredEvidence.description: SCO confirmation that asset was in institution's ownership before sale
Analysis showing: (1) Purchase from supplier → (2) Inventory entry → (3) Sale to customer
Confirmation that institution had constructive possession (control/risk)

policyConstraints.constraint: CRITICAL: Customer Murabaha sale contract cannot be executed until asset is in institution's inventory
Regulatory requirement: Documentation must show asset ownership sequence

criticalNote: ⚠️ HARD GATE: Selling an asset before owning it (bay' al-ma'dum) is prohibited in Shariah. Institution must purchase asset → enter in inventory → THEN sell to customer via Murabaha. This distinguishes Murabaha from conventional financing.
